title: 108_s1190
content: The Act titled "Next Generation Hispanic Serving Institutions Act" establishes postbaccalaureate opportunities for Hispanic Americans under Title V of the Higher Education Act of 1965. This includes redesignating sections and promoting postbaccalaureate opportunities for Hispanic Americans. Congress finds that by 2050, 1 in 4 Americans will be of Hispanic origin. Despite this growth, Hispanics are underrepresented in advanced degrees and instructional faculty in the United States. Increasing the number of Hispanics pursuing postbaccalaureate studies is crucial for future research and advanced study capacity. Hispanic-serving institutions are leading in increasing Hispanics attaining graduate and professional degrees. 25% of Hispanics who received master's degrees in 1999-2000 earned them at these institutions. Between 1991 and 2000, the number of Hispanic students earning master's degrees at these institutions grew significantly. Expanding the capacity of Hispanic-serving institutions for graduate and professional degree programs is in the national interest. The role of research at Hispanic-serving institutions is crucial for graduate education and undergraduate preparation in science and technology. University research is integral to the institution's mission. The purposes of this part include expanding educational opportunities for Hispanic students and improving their academic attainment, as well as enhancing postbaccalaureate academic offerings for Hispanic college students and low-income individuals. "SEC. 512. Program authorized for competitive grants to eligible Hispanic-serving institutions offering postbaccalaureate programs. SEC. 513. Authorized activities include expanding educational opportunities and enhancing postbaccalaureate offerings." Grants awarded under this part can be used for purchasing scientific equipment, improving educational facilities, buying educational materials, and supporting postbaccalaureate students in need. The grants awarded under this part can be used for scholarships, faculty support, facilities improvement for distance learning, collaboration with other institutions, and other activities that contribute to the program's purposes. The grants awarded under this part can be used for scholarships, faculty support, facilities improvement for distance learning, collaboration with other institutions, and other activities that contribute to the program's purposes. Approved by the Secretary as part of the review and acceptance of such application. "SEC. 514. APPLICATION AND DURATION." The application for grants under this part must demonstrate how funds will improve postbaccalaureate education for Hispanic and low-income students, leading to greater financial independence. Grants awarded will not exceed 5 years, with a limitation of one grant per Hispanic-serving institution per fiscal year. Cooperative arrangements are amended, and appropriations are authorized. Authorization of appropriations for parts A and B of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended for fiscal year 2005 and the following 4 years. Conforming amendments are made to section 502 of the Act. The text chunk involves amendments to various sections of the Higher Education Act of 1965, changing references from one section to another. Amendments are made to the Higher Education Act of 1965, including redefining definitions, authorizing activities like articulation agreements, and eliminating the wait-out period for students. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 include eliminating the wait-out period for students and prioritizing grant applications for Hispanic-serving institutions.
